questionListItems.title: My husband and I are co-owners of a property. Why do we see two amounts when we log in to myTax Portal? Are both owners required to pay?

answer.body: Property tax is a tax levied on property ownership. The payment arrangement on the property tax payable is a private matter to be settled among the property owners. If one of the owners has made payment, the co-owner is not required to make another payment for the same property. Both owners will be able to view the same amount in myTax Portal as it is tied to the same property.

questionListItems.title: If I own and occupy more than one residential property concurrently, what will be the tax rates applied?

answer.body: The owner-occupier tax rates are only granted to one property owned and occupied by you. For subsequent properties, you will be taxed at non-owner-occupier residential tax rates even if you are occupying it as your second home.

questionListItems.title: How does IRAS determine the Annual Value (AV) of my residential property?

answer.body:
The Annual Value (AV) is the estimated gross annual rent of the property if it were to be rented out, excluding furniture, furnishings and maintenance fees. It is determined based on estimated market rentals of similar or comparable residential properties and not on the actual rental income received.


The way the AV is determined is the same regardless of whether the property is owner-occupied, vacant or rented out.

questionListItems.title: Who qualifies for owner-occupier tax rates?

answer.body: You (as an individual or a married couple) must own and reside in the residential property to qualify for owner-occupier tax rates. If you are a married couple that owns 2 homes, the concession can only be applied to 1 home. Please note that even if a married couple were to occupy two homes, the owner-occupier tax rates can only apply to one of the homes. This is regardless of whether it is owned jointly or separately by the spouses.

questionListItems.title: My salary is paid by my foreign employer in my home country/region. Am I liable to Singapore income tax?

answer.body: Yes, income earned for the period you render your services is taxable in Singapore. Taxable income includes your salary, bonus, allowances and housing provided by the foreign employer and the local sponsor company.

topics.title: General tax matters (for NOR or those with foreign employer)

questionListItems.title: I am a self-employed person and have not been filing my income tax return as my income is below the income filing threshold requirements. However, I need my tax bill (i.e. Notice of Assessment) for the Year of Assessment (YA) 2024 to apply for government assistance scheme. How can I get my tax bill?

answer.body:
You can e-File your Income Tax Return for the YA 2024 at myTax Portal between 1 Mar 2024 and 31 Oct 2024. This only applies to self-employed persons who did not receive any notification to file but require the tax bill.

If you encounter any issue when trying to e-File your Income Tax Return, please chat with us or call us from Monday to Friday, 8:00 am to 5:00 pm (except Public Holidays). Alternatively, you can email us via myTax Mail with your Singpass.

questionListItems.title: IRAS requires the annual income information but the CPF submissions are done monthly. How will the data from CPF Board be reflected at the 'Submit Employment Income records' digital service?

answer.body:
The monthly income and deduction information e-Submitted to CPF Board for each employee will be summed up and pre-filled as the annual income.

Note:
If you use a different CSNs with the same UEN (e.g. 12345678A-PTE-01 and 12345678A-PTE-02), all the employees' information under the respective CSNs will be summed up.

topics.title: AIS - Sign up for CPF Data Link-up Service

questionListItems.title: Will my claims, refunds or adjustments to CPF Board be reflected at the 'Submit Employment Income Records' digital service?

answer.body:
Any claims, refund or adjustments made to CPF submissions will not be reflected at the digital service.

You will have to adjust the pre-filled data before submitting the information to IRAS.

topics.title: AIS - Sign up for CPF Data Link-up Service

questionListItems.title: If the contribution details were not e-Submitted to CPF Board by 14 Jan, will the information be pre-filled at the 'Submit Employment Income Records' digital service?

answer.body:
To obtain complete information for contributions made from Jan to Dec of the year, submissions to CPF Board must be done by 14 Jan of the following year. Submissions made after 14 Jan will not be pre-filled.

For example
If the CPF contribution for the month of Dec 2024 is submitted after 14 Jan 2025, the data for Dec 2024 will not be pre-filled for the YA 2025 submission. You will have to manually add the income information for Dec 2024 at the digital service.

topics.title: AIS - Sign up for CPF Data Link-up Service

questionListItems.title: Do employers need to fill in ‘Date of Commencement’ and ‘Date of Cessation’ field(s) in the Form IR8A?

answer.body:
Employers will need to provide the date of commencement if the employee commenced employment in the year or before 1 Jan 1969. Fill in the ‘Date of Cessation’ if your employee ceased employment in the year.

To fill in the Form IR8A for 2023 (Year of Assessment 2024):

1.   If employee joined on 1 Dec 1968 but did not cease employment, the employer should fill in ‘Date of Commencement’ as ‘01/12/1968’ and leave the ‘Date of Cessation’ as blank

2.   If employee joined on 15 Jan 2023 and ceased employment on 20 Aug 2023, the employer should fill in the ‘Date of Commencement’ as ‘15/01/2023’ and ‘Date of Cessation as ‘20/08/2023’

3.   If the employee joined on 25 Feb 2017 and ceased employment on 1 Nov 2023, the employer should leave the ‘Date of Commencement’ as blank and fill in the ‘Date of Cessation’ as ‘01/11/2023’

topics.title: AIS - Reporting Employee Earnings (IR8A, Appendix 8A, Appendix 8B, IR8S)

questionListItems.title: Should I include maintenance fees when stamping my tenancy agreement?

answer.body: The information stamped should be based on what is reflected in your tenancy agreement. If management fees is one of the considerations stated in the agreement, it should be included as part of your contractual rent when stamping your document.

questionListItems.title: Do I need to stamp if I am only renting out a room to a friend or family member? There is no tenancy agreement, just verbal agreement.

answer.body:
Stamp Duty is a tax on document (physical or electronic).


If there is no physical document but the tenancy arrangement was made via electronic modes such as WhatsApp, email, websites, SMS, stamping is still required, and stamp duty is payable.


Otherwise, stamping is not required and Stamp Duty is not payable.

questionListItems.title: I'm a Singaporean, intending to jointly purchase a condo with my husband who is a US Citizen.
questionListItems.body:
This will be my 2nd residential property as I am an owner of a HDB. My husband does not own any residential property.
How will the Additional Buyer’s Stamp Duty (ABSD) be computed on our joint purchase?

answer.body:
For purchases involving multiple buyers with different profiles, the higher applicable ABSD rate will be used.


As your spouse is a US Citizen, he will be eligible for the same Stamp Duty treatment as Singapore Citizens under the Free Trade Agreement ABSD Remission.


Given that this joint purchase will be your second residential property and you own an HDB, ABSD at the applicable rate will be imposed on the higher of the purchase price or market value.

questionListItems.title: Am I able to arrange for my Additional Buyer’s Stamp Duty (ABSD) to be deducted from my CPF account?

answer.body:
As Stamp Duty is payable within 14 days from the date of purchase, you will need to:


  1. Pay Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) in cash first.


  2. Subsequently obtain reimbursement from your CPF account.


Drawing upon CPF savings to pay Stamp Duty is under CPF's purview. For further clarification, please contact CPF Board.

questionListItems.title: What are the Stamp Duty payment modes available?

answer.body: You may refer to How to pay Stamp Duty for the payment modes available for Stamp Duty.
